name: TV Computer
ram: 32 KB or 64 KB, depending on models
graphics: 128 x 240 (16 colors), 256 x 240 (4 colors), 512 x 240 (2 colors)
size: 46 (W) x 19 (D) x 11(H) cm / 2.8 kg (+ 0.8 kg for the separate PSU)
ports: Cassette interface, Centronics, 2 x joystick connectors, 1 cartridge slot, 4 expansion slots (8 KB ROM max. each)
description:
This computer was used in the 80's in Hungarian schools along with the Primo. It was very similar to the Enterprise 64 as it was a licensed product. There is even a built-in joystick on the right of the keyboard.

There are different models : 32 KB, 64 KB and 64 KB+ (picture here). The 64 KB+ has more video RAM (64 KB instead of 16 KB) and different versions of ROM (2.1 - 2.2 & 2.4 instead of 1.1 -1.2 - 1.3 & 1.4).

The main physical difference of the TV-Computer is the four expansion slots that are placed at the top left side of the case, allowing easy upgrade of the system. On the left side, one can find two joystick connectors and a cartridge slot (16 KB max.) for games, applications and operating systems. TVC OS is built-in the system (along with Basic), but UPM (special version of CP/M for the TVC) or VT-DOS (DOS 3.10 compatible) could be implemented this way. VT-DOS could only read/write IBM PC disks, as it was not fully compatible with both the hardware and software.

Thanks to Gabor Monok for all the info & pictures!
_______________________

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert shows all the tools a software developer could run on the MorthStar computers range (Horizon and Advantage) </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A computer for all french people"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 84'S PARIS-DAKAR RACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A KAYPRO IV IN ACTION SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA <br><br> 8 Kaypro IV and 2 Kaypro 10 were used by the doctors of the Paris-Dakar race 84's edition. The Kaypro IVs were used to store medical information about the 1000 participants. Power was provided by the Mercedes cars through the 12v cigarette lighters. The Kaypro 10s were kept in the "communication" plane during the day, and were used to centralize all the informations in the evening. At the end of the race, and after 12000 km of tracks, there were all running fine ! One of the Kaypro 10 is said to have been thrown out of the plane, mistaken with a common metallic tool box... And it still worked !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>An 80's beautiful (!) woman tries to convince us that it's very exciting to work with an Alpha Plus...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing is very simple with the AIM65 from Rockwell"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PREVIOUS SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Before manufacturing the MPC, Columbia tried to sell a massive multi-user, Z80 based system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"List your technical requirements, Hewlett-Packard is ready to answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US DEALER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, parents interested in expanding their children's educational experience, turned to expensive encyclopedias. With the advent of the PET personal computer a new avenue of visual learning is now available for your youngsters for as low as $595....<br><br> ... Your youngster will think he's playing, you'll know he's learning with the remarkable PET... </font><br><br> At the time, parents often thought a personal computer could help their youngsters learning, but 80% of the home computers sold in the 80's was used only for playing. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Douglas Reedy</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (FEB. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Educatel advert for their correspondance courses using the Microlab system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Karl-Heinz  -  www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This detailed advert presents a complete EXL-100 with all the pripherals available then (printer, disk, tape, modem, carts, etc.).  <br><br> "Exelvision, the french micro-computing challenge"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE FLYER - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dealer price list - August 1986</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

emulator.name: TVC 2.18
emulator.description: Hungarian emulator written by Laszlo Toth

emulator.name: WinTVC
emulator.description: arian emulator for Windows, with disk emulation

peripherals: Tape recorder, UART (Async. receiver/transmitter, with 8251), Floppy Interface (2 x 720 KB FDD)
